page.title: 03ST.GEORGE'S CHURCH,RODINGTON
page.content: RODINGTON IS ONLY A SMALL PARISH BUT IT HAS A CHURCH, AND HAS HAD ONE SINCE BEFORE THE ORIGINAL DOMESDAY BOOK. AS IT STANDS NOW IT IS BUILT OF STONE AND BRICK. THE ROOF IS TILED. THERE ARE ELEVEN WINDOWS. THEY ARE ALL ARCHED. THE GLASS IS HELD IN PLACE BY LEAD STRIPS IN A DIAMOND PATTERN. FOUR OF THE WINDOWS HAVE PICTURES IN THEM. THE BIG WINDOWS HAVE THREE LITTLE CIRCLES AT THE TOP IN A FLOWER SHAPE. THERE IS A WOODEN STEEPLE WITH TWO BELLS IN. ON TOP OF THIS THERE IS A WEATHER VANE. IT USED TO BE A COCKEREL BUT NOW IT IS AN ARROW. IT WAS MADE BY A BLACKSMITH AT THE NEAR BY VILLAGE OF LONGDON. STUART'S GRANDAD HELD THE LADDER AND ENCOURAGED THE BLACKSMITH WHEN HE TOOK IT UP BECAUSE IT WAS VERY HIGH. A GATE ERECTED TO CELEBRATE GEORGE V'S JUBILEE IN 1935 STILL STANDS.
